Author: rickbullotta
Content:
As long as it isn't garbage data, which is often is.  All three components are prone to inaccuracy.  Q being the most common.  Also the rated capacity used in "P" is usually a bullshit number, and should often be specific to a product and/or lot size and/or line.  And "A" is one of the most often misunderstood particularly with how setup/changeover time(s) are factored in (some give a free pass to any changeover time, others start the downtime clock after the "standard" changeover time).  And very few properly account for the upstream and downstream interdependencies of all three metrics.  Bottom line is that they're all rather unreliable in the real world.  Add to that how many OEE/downtime tracking systems ask the operator to specify the reason (at a time when they should be focused on getting the line up and running) and you tend to get garbage information on balance.

Anyone with a functioning brain can simply spend a few days on the line, watching, speaking with the operators, analyzing available data and determine where the bottlenecks and issues are.  And of these, "speaking with the operators" may be the most illuminating...

Author: markritchie8899
Content: Detecting a shift in you process is only looking at the process output against your control limits using the Westinghouse rules (1 Point out of Spec, 2 of 3 > 2 Sigma on same side of mean, 4 of 5 > 1 Sigma on same side of mean, etc.). So,  real time drift would be the signal coming from your process output against the control limits. Knowing Cp & Cpk allows you to calculate the Effective Cost of Production (ECP). If Cp= 3.0 (Specs are 3 x wider than limits) and a Cpk = 3.0 then the ECP of a $1.00 part is $1.01 (occasional reject). if the process was to drift to Cpk = 2.5 then the ECP would rise to $1.04. Because of the process capability you still have wiggle room till you‚Äôre out of spec which gives you time to recenter the process. This gives an indication of the cost impact of poor quality.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Headless BI is the natural evolution of a data warehouse when you move to a data-lake (or lake-house?) model. 
What I mean by that is "Headless BI" used to mean that you could get access to consistent, modelled, business specific, cleansed data from your data warehouse. The semantic model and business logic for building report-ready or analysis-ready data lived in the ETL configuration or code.

A data-lake moves away from that and loads raw data into the "Data Staging Layer" in the diagram, and then transforms into report-ready or analysis-ready data from there. (Extract, Load then transform rather than Extract, Transform then Load )

So I would argue that BI has always been headless if you had a well structured Data Warehouse, and was only ever not-headless if business logic was put into the BI tool rather than the data-warehouse.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
The OEE question is a bit of a lively subject, and is either seen as a great tool or useless depending on who you talk to.  I'm more in the former category provided it's used correctly.  You seem to have collected much of the datapoints that you will need to create the metric, now the challenge is to build the metric itself.  My view on this is that the three components of OEE, throughput, quality, and availability should be weighted depending on the requirements of the organization.  If the company is in an industry like pharma, they're probably going to really care about the quality aspect, while a facility that is manufacturing low cost goods is probably going to be more concerned about throughput.  Just remember, OEE really only works once a baseline has been established and is really only meant to be an indicator.

Once you get rolling with this, you may want to additional inputs, for instance, we've seen a couple places create an operator input tag, where the operator can select a reason for downtime.  Needs to be kept pretty simple to be effective, but can provide some good insight as to why a machine was down.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Even OEE's constituent metrics are only valuable if they are accurate and frequently re-baselined after process and equipment changes.  Which pretty much no one does.  And "quality" is generally a horrifically inaccurate measure in most OEE implementations.  If you're not also measuring safety, supply chain, and sustainability metrics, you're doing it wrong.  It all comes down to this diagram, and all the OEE in the world won't get you in the ideal quadrant.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
I don't disagree with anything you've said, but OEE is really only meant to be an indicator, and not the main one at that.  It is meant as a 30k ft view, and when one of the metrics starts to move, it should indicate a need to investigate.  Further, like any indicator, they need to be audited every so often to ensure that they aren't being manipulated, or that they are still valid.  I would think that a good OEE KPI would at least get you to "D", and considering it's an operational metric, that's as far as it needs to get you.  Also, while I don't disagree with what you said, I do think it would be interesting to compare OEE before and after process and equipment changes to determine the impact.

Content: TBC on UPH. If you believe that for all the machines in all manufacturing the UPH is ONLY what the machine manufacturer wrote in the spec as max speed, you are wrong. As you probably hinted, the UPH has a lot to do with the Product that you run on that line, on that machine. Let's talk about your iPhone. And you get what? Max 80% of the theoretical max speed is your achievable operational max... If the manufacturers of the machines would be more honest...maybe you can achieve UPH closer to their theoretical max. SMT lines have pretty complex UPH calculations depending on hundreds of factors and the performance of your optimisation software that has to optimise perfectly for speed and quality thousands of placements... something like this https://youtu.be/ylk6VMBLrvM

Author: hobbes1069
Content: So for discrete manufacturing with multiple steps, how do you calculate OEE? One of the steps will be the constraint, so do you not measure Productivity at non-constraints? They will at some point be starved for work.

Author: nickn5549
Content: If the group of workcells/production lines/steps are part of a 'one-piece flow' the TAKT TIME of the whole sequence of workcells is calculated based on the Cycle Time of the bottleneck workcell and then based on this TAKT you get the UPH (Units Per Hour) for the whole group. After that you measure OEE for each workcell. Starved workcells won't get penalised in terms of Availability, but their Performance will suffer. Rolled-up OEE, for the whole group, is the AVG of all the OEEs...some get fancy and do a weighted AVG (something based on how much added value each workcell adds). If you allow big buffers after each workcell you can use the UPH of each workcell in the calculation of the OEE (ignoring the bottleneck) and plan/justify to re-balance the line (sometimes add more workcells/eqp) to eliminate the bottleneck and improve OEE (Performance part).

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I recently spent a day facilitating a workshop with executives at one of the sites within a multi-national manufacturing enterprise. At the end of the day, I walked through the factory with the site manager.
Where are your biggest opportunities? I asked. "I have no idea", was his honest response. 
"We have a bunch of performance reports, but they are all bullshit. Our performance is heavily influenced by product mix and schedule, and the reports don't take that into account"
The site manager is a rising star within the company, and for good reason. He had managed to lift the performance of the site across a broad range of measures. When I asked how he did it, I was not surprised by his answer, but it is sad for the state of the industry.
"I spent months out here with a clip-board and a stop watch doing time and motion studies. Turns out our bottle neck is not what we thought, and it moves around depending on the product and order sizes. We got the improvement through basic scientific method and a lot of hard work"
OEE is worse than a bad KPI, it's fake news. The truth about operations performance, particularly in manually intensive processes like at this factory is very difficult to find, but worth a lot when you find it.

Author: remco.poelarends
Content:
There are a lot of videos and discussions about OEE and I have used it to monitor systems to determine improvements on systems. Currently I am working on a case where I think OEE could be used to control systems and the quality of the product instead of only using it for monitoring and I am curious whether anyone has used this. 
The case in short; I have a system which can and should execute 2 processes on each single product after each other but the processes can execute in parallel within the system on 2 different products, so product 1 has been processed with process A and being processed with process B and product 2 is being processed at process A. Each product is unique and this implies different processing times for process A and B.
The performance (OEE-P) of the system is determined by the slowest process and the quality of the product (OEE-Q) can be influenced by the time a process is executed, e.g. taking more time will improve the quality.
As such, a decline in OEE-P has an positive impact on OEE-Q and vice versa.
Could you in this case use the overall OEE-P*Q finding the optimum for each specific process / product?
Or can you also apply the concept of OEE on a product instead of on the equipment determining the "Overall Product (production) Efficiency" for each individual product and adjust the system accordingly?
I am curious if anyone has experienced the case that faster (higher OEE-P) is not always better?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Of course.  Higher OEE-P can lead to reduced quality, premature machine or tooling failure or wear, disproportionately high energy usage, an increase in safety incidents, and lots of side effects.  That's why even OEE needs to be viewed along with many other KPIs, not just the "big three".   There is nothing wrong with creating your own, more meaningful KPIs either.

Author: sandves
Content:
Hello everyone! I have some questions regarding utilization and OEE.

I am a consultant currently working for a manufacturing company that is producing parts primarily for the oil and gas industry (sub sea). They mostly do high mix low volume make-to-order manufacturing where CNC machines are the most important machine assets. I think around 60% of the parts they produce are new parts that they make for the first time.

They have an IIOT solution that is collecting data from the machines and they have a simple utilization calculation that they call "power-on utilization". This is basically *uptime / total power-on time*. It does not take into account planned production time, performance or quality which makes it a rather weak KPI in my opinion. The uptime / downtime classification is based on machine states, which gives them some insight about the different downtimes but I would say it is insufficient as a foundation for improvements. You get to see how much time was spent in idle, alarm, manual mode etc. but you don't know why. Was it idle for an hour due to inspection of the part? Was it setup or change-over? Planned service? First of all, have you ever heard of this way of calculating utilization before? Is it an established KPI?

I started looking into OEE and thought it would be a natural next step from this simple calculation. I learned that OEE is also a super simple mathematical expression. The hard part is collecting the data required to derive the three factors of OEE accurately.

**Availability**
In order to calculate availability I would need to integrate with the ERP system to find info about shifts, planned orders. I guess I need to look up data about planned maintenance from a maintenance system. What about classification of downtimes in the machine? I do not wish to demand that operators spend time on manually classifying downtimes. I also doubt that data quality would be any good. Do you normally try to do this automatically or give them suggestions?

**Performance**
I can easily find good count and planned production time in the ERP system, but how on earth do you calculate ideal cycle time in an environment with high mix and mostly new parts that has never been made?

**Quality**
Good parts and scrapped parts are fine. But who is to be "punished" for the scrap? Is it the asset that scrapped the part, or is it the neighbouring asset spending the rest of the week doing rework? 

What about NCE's / deviations? Parts could be rejected and returned from the customer months after it was manufactured. How should this affect OEE?

**Scope / time frame**
If understand these factors correctly, OEE could not be used as a real time KPI (which many seem to do anyway ü§î). It has to be evaluated over a period of time. What scope or time frame do you suggest? Day, shift, work order, anything else?

It seems like everyone is finding OEE so easy and therefore it makes sense to start with OEE and build other KPIs down the road. I have to admit that I am bit pessimistic about developing a robust solution with an OEE based on high data quality within a reasonable budget. I also feel it would require some sort of cultural change management if they want to benefit from OEE. In my experience, the focus has been to tweak the calculations or do "hacks" in the processes to boost the utilization numbers. Instead, I think the focus should be on the underlying factors and shed light on all the losses so that you know where to focus your improvement work. Who is OEE meant for actually? ü§î 

Am I overthinking this?

This post became a lot longer than excpected, but I hope some of you experienced smart people out there will take the time to read it and share your points of view.

Author: marco_moiron
Content:
I have a KPI-related question and I would appreciate your opinion.
In our industry, the cement production industry, due to the irregularity of the raw materials and alternative fuels' quality and physical characteristics, we don't rely much on real-time KPIs, especially at a management level. Most of our Production, Quality, and Maintenance KPIs are all period-based averages (event or time-based), integrations, etc.: "Shift average electric specific consumption (kWh/t)", "Month average productivity (t/h)", "YTD MTBF (h)" are some examples. Therefore, historical data is needed to perform these calculations.
Since the UNS' MQTT broker, by definition, only stores the last value of each variable, there is no elegant way of achieving this in Ignition. The apparent solution (and in reality, it's how we are handling it currently) would be to calculate everything in the historian. However, we are striving to avoid proprietary scripting languages (as we learned that lesson the hard way).
Another alternative would be to perform these calculations in the AWS infrastructure (or some other cloud provider) using the specific time-series tools available. Our concern in this case revolves around the cost of transmitting the necessary tens of thousands of variables per plant, each with a resolution of a few seconds, to the cloud.
Your insights are highly valued.

Best regards,

Marco

Author: douglasalbright
Content:
In the cases like you mentioned, we're addressing customer concerns about the costs of moving large amounts of data by using on-site business intelligence. While our approach utilizes IA and MS SQL, it's not tied to any specific technology. It's crucial to distinguish between creating a BI resource and the decision to move data to the cloud. Cloud providers often blur these lines for marketing reasons, but by focusing on the necessary architecture, we can avoid vendor lock-in and keep costs low.

Furthermore, by leveraging Low-Code development practices, augmented with LLM coding assistance, we can speed up our work and utilize established models. This approach not only accelerates development but also enables customers to use these models as an expert system. In light of recent advancements, we should all reconsider our estimations on what we can develop in-house based on LLM advancements.

The tie-in with the UNS is that it allows for a reference back to the originating point of the data, providing analysts with a single contact point when they need to know where data came from.

By focusing on strongly typing our originating events, we can better support plans to leverage platforms like Snowflake. When we considered methods that would move everything in the UNS up to the cloud, it became apparent that we needed to be more selective. This approach still supports the fundamental benefit of establishing the semantic name space, allowing us to meet our goals without incurring unnecessary costs or complexity.

Author: nickn5549
Content: It is a lot of work. We have an 'Engineering Model' for each product that defines the cycle time on each machine and moves/places the bottleneck on the most expensive asset (something that cannot be easily duplicated). CTs are calculated by software that spits out the programs for the machines. For manual processes, we involve M.O.S.T methodology to calculate the optimum CT for processes. Once you do all this work and the Eng Model is complete, you know what output to expect at 100% efficiency provided that all other constraints are not choking you - Machines Availability, Direct and/or Indirect Resources, Quality, Materials, etc. Now you are ready to measure and see how well your predicted CT matches the real world.

I find Goodhart's to be a very British establishment remark in that it is pithy and not very useful. and in it's context of the Cobra bounty, it would be better expressed as " When a measure of a process is incentivised it ceases to be a good measure of the process"

I think there are laws lots of measures that are targets and remain good measures, Accident rates in Aviation, NPS,
And certainly there are measures that are good measures for a process but do not have a linear relations ship so as the score improves, the measure and the process become less linked

 I prefer from Wheeler, "When people are pressured to meet a target value there are three ways they can proceed:

1) They can work to improve the system
2) They can distort the system
3) Or they can distort the data"

and that calls us to 
Make it difficult to distort the system  - a bit more inherently difficult in manufacturing compared to breading cobras perhaps, but automated/Assisted workflow management helps here 
Make it difficult to distort the data,    - Automatic collection of OEE data
Give people the slack necessary to improve the system  - Listen to the voice of the Operators,

All things I tink most people on this Discord would agree with,

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Let me share some of the KPIs that Litmus customers are doing - just sharing them for information purposes. I discovered some of them during my last plant visits.

**1. Planned vs. Reality**
- Comparing planning from SAP (Yield, Scrap or anything) and real data from the plant floor from Litmus Edge 
- Push data from Litmus Edge to SAP and draw a chart.
- Optimize in the upcoming runs. 

**2. OEM Spec vs. Reality **
- Compare an asset/machine spec vs what is the current runtime reality 
- A beer bottle packaging machine had 12000 / hour in spec, and they were doing 11,400 / hour even at the spec speed (this is what the customer got from Litmus Edge + Siemens + Data loggers combo). 
- They asked OEM to find the bottleneck and optimize it. They are a happy customer for life.

**3. Total Volume NOT Produced today. **
- This is a financial KPI. It directly goes to¬†the P&L¬†holder and¬†, in some¬†cases, the¬†board.¬†
- How much were a plant supposed to produce vs. how much were we produced? 
- We had a big fight between the plant manager and corporate about this KPI.

**4. Batch deviations **
- Compare realtime 50-60 variable golden batch vs current. 
- Used for long-running and precious chemical processes 
- Identify early indications via ML and dump the batch if needed. 

**5. Smart Asset Health (this is an amazing one!)**
- A customer created a custom asset health KPI in the Litmus Edge analytics layer.
- Merging Utilization / some ML predictions / previous failover combinations. It was the multiplication and division of many KPIs 
- Did a trend/prediction on that custom Smart Asset Health and schedule maintenance. 
- They push that KPI to Ignition / FTView as well for incremental feedback from the operator.

It comes down to how you treat OEE.  If you're setting KPIs for the WC that they need to maintain a certain OEE, then that's unfair.  

In my opinion:
  The OEE KPI should be held accountable at the Plant manager level.   
    The A KPI should be owned by say, Maintenance (is the machine broken) / Planning (are materials available as expected) / Line Super (are people available to run the machine).
    The P KPI should be owned by ProcessEng (are the standards correct, is the process correct) / Operator (are they slacking off and they have to press a button to advance to the next process step)
    The Q KPI - most folks don't actually measure it well enough to bother, and when they do, it's general so lagging that it's mostly irrelevant. So just toss it. (or peg it at some number that is generally representative of reality so that people feel good about seeing the number)

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
That's normal. Theoretical cycle times can vary product, process, asset / workcenter, tooling, labor resources, etc. Beyond tracking performance, this especially important for scheduling. It's important to factor in these as constraints to determine realistic capacity or throughput.

The ERP layer should define the products, BOMs, routings (operations/processes), and the compatible workcenters than can run the process. There should be a theoretical rates (standard rate, ideal rate, etc) defined for each possible production configuration. You could even get more granular having rates down to the resource level.

It's super important to audit and maintain these rates. It's good to have both an automated and manual way of doing this. Ideally, machine programs should have cycle timers that can be monitored. Adding a time study as a step to an engineering change workflow is not a bad practice.

So, when a work order is scheduled to a particular workcenter, one can utilize the relevant rate for calculating performance metrics. 

From a reporting standpoint, if you have a lot of variation in the theoretical rates, it might make sense to include a comparison of relative (e.g., OEE, efficiency) and absolute (qty produced) metrics as a reality check. Relative metrics can sometimes "hide" waste and perpetuate conventional wisdom about operations, Someone should be asking, for example, whether their should be variation within a similar product family or whether a line is performing as intiailly budgeted.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
I have definitely started to believe that using OEE as a KPI often covers up many underlying issues. I already had this opinion, but now I‚Äôve become completely fixated on it.

For example, during a meeting with a company, I asked the production manager: if the theoretical machine capacity is 100 tons per day, but only 50 tons are produced due to low demand, why would we calculate the KPI based on 50 tons? This would show high efficiency and might not create pressure on the sales team. But is production separate from the rest of the business? Wouldn‚Äôt it be better for everyone to see the real reasons behind the issue and take action? Wouldn‚Äôt this create pressure on the sales department? Production will do its job well, but it won‚Äôt share the responsibility for sales.

Doesn‚Äôt this also mean that we might end up producing products we can‚Äôt sell? For instance, to avoid setup times, we might overproduce and stock excess inventory, increasing storage costs. No one will question this because the OEE looks high. Is this business truly efficient?

The pressure to keep machines running and not let efficiency drop could lead to wasting energy and resources unnecessarily.

For example, a company that couldn‚Äôt manage its inventory invested heavily in an automated warehouse. They spent ‚Ç¨2.5 million, and now they can store around 3,000 tons of products. But why are these products sitting in the warehouse? Why aren‚Äôt they being shipped? I integrated this warehouse with SAP, and at the time, it seemed like a fantastic investment. But now, when I reflect on it, it doesn‚Äôt seem right.

Whenever we say that OEE is still necessary, other critical KPIs are ignored by production. It feels like the business doesn‚Äôt operate as a whole. Using OEE appears to result in harmful outcomes.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: When the cost of quality is high, it's quite possible to have a higher OEE but much worse economic performance.  Also, what good is a high OEE If workplace accidents and injuries are also high?  It does little to help identify bottlenecks, it punishes operators/workcenters for upstream or downstream issues, and is almost always very inaccurate (only a tiny fraction of processes can truly measure it in realtime).  It really is a hopelessly flawed metric for countless reasons.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
I'm not a fan of explaining OEE as OEE = A*P*Q. The common formulas for A,P,Q are overly simplified, and don't state the assumptions behind them. If the assumptions and subsequent simplifications were not applied, the APQ formulas would all be units of "effective time" instead of "counts". This is also subtly hinted in oee.com documentation.

For example the common A formula assumes that input/output counts do not change during machine downtime (but the OEM provides state based on current draw of a motor and there is some lag, so unfortunately that assumption isn't perfect during state transitions). 2nd example, P/Q formulas assume constant standard rate. What if I run multiple materials?

OEE is (effective time spent making good parts)/(scheduled time). This is generally a lot easier to conceptualize/calculate then all the semantics that go into APQ calculations. If you want to accurately calculate OEE and OEEbased-APQ, start with the OEE calculation, then work backwards with the data you are provided to get A, P, Q formulas. The decisions made will be directly related to the quality of data/signals available, as you've stated.

One can argue if a loss of effective time is categorized as APQ, but a single loss event should not show up twice. How does the time spent making a bad part during unplanned downtime affect APQ and OEE vs if no part was made during that time? The OEE result should be the same. How does the time spent making a good part during unplanned  downtime affect APQ and OEE vs if no part was made during that time? Should OEE good counts match the count applied towards the work order? Micro stops should just push losses between A/P, but not affect OEE. Thinking in terms of "effective time" instead of "counts" makes these decisions more digestible.

Content:
Hi all, curious for people opinions on OEE in this circumstance - my client is a large factory that builds timber frames and trusses for houses, almost entirely automated, with large saws, nail presses, pickers, etc cutting and assembling the components based on the engineering plans.

Each cell has on board HMI and control, but there is no site wide system connecting the different assets. Each order is broken down first into individual elements (walls or trusses) which are then broken into sub-elements (studs, lintels, beams, etc.) which are cut and assembled progressively at different equipment stations.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
You can take one of two approaches.

For each machine determine the peak performance. Maybe it is feed rate or maybe it is units. And you stick with that and all performance is rated again that.

The other approach is to adjust the rate based on the sub component. So if you are cutting 2 ft lengths or 4 ft lengths the peak performance might be different.

Though in those cases I would argue feed rate is a better measure of performance.
